boardgame.name: Uno Studio In Smeraldo
A Study in Emerald
boardgame.description: A Study in Emerald is a game for two to five players based on the award-winning short story of the same name by Neil Gaiman. In this stylistic mash-up of Sherlock Holmes and H.P. Lovecraft, the worst has already happened and the world is now ruled by the Old Ones. However, a secret war is being fought to free mankind from their servitude. The game A Study in Emerald fleshes out this core idea by including historical figures from the late nineteenth century, most being persons involved in the anarchist movement of the time._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Deck-building forms the core of the game. You use influence cubes to bid for the right to draft cards and take control of cities. Each player has a secret identity, either a Restorationist fighting against the creatures or a Loyalist attempting to defend the status quo. Which side you are on determines what you score points for. An additional twist is that the performance of other players on the same side as you can stop you from winning if they are doing particularly badly, so you really want to know who is on which side. More specifically, when the game ends _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;ndash; and this can result from multiple causes, such as a marker on the War or Revolution track hitting 15 or the assassination of a Restorationist player agent _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;ndash; then the sides compare their scores; which side has the lowest score automatically loses, then the player with the highest score on the remaining team wins the game._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;The game takes around ninety minutes to play and is more complex than most, so more suitable for the experienced gamer._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;

Unplayed but opened to make sure all parts are present. And Good news: Because I opened and counted the pieces, I was able to get the missing red counters from Treefrog Games. One note: one of the Zombie markers was broken. When I super-glued it back together, the super glue spilled out of the bottle. I did a good job getting the excess off the zombie, but in doing so, some of the gray paint came off as well. Unfortunately, Tree Frog did not send a replacement zombie, despite my request. In all, I_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;d say that this copy is better than new: red counters are present and the broken Zombie is whole, albeit a little less gray.
